body:
Thanks :) 

I think the problem would arise here from the fact that x is a list where list items are arrays. What are you trying to achieve by doing it?

Thank you for your response. as my model needs multiple input, so I want to pass my train data as list to the Scan function. Is it correct? Or how can I do let the multiple input function work with talos? Or can you modify the code I proposed as an example.
Thankyou

It's still not clear for me why you want to input multiple inputs to a single Keras model? Could you explain more about your use-case. 

Right now you can't input a list in to Scan().

Hi, I also really like to use talos, and I have the same list as input situation here.

And my use-case is from here:
http://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/jdwittenauer/ipython-notebooks/blob/master/notebooks/keras/StructuredTimeSeries.ipynb

Overall, the idea is that you need to input each of the category features in your data to keras embedding layer to output the embedding matrix for each category feature. So for each category feature you need one input layer which will need a list of input array in keras. But besides this user-case, I think in RNN LSTM model, it also needs multiple inputs.

I am still new and please correct me if anything wrong or there is better way to do this. Thank you so much for this.
Thanks a lot @lawrencechiukj for the great example notebook. I will try to look into this over the next few days.

issue.title: Modification to run with multi-output models

labels.name: topic: data
labels.description: Has to do with input or output data

repository.name: talos
repository.description: Hyperparameter Optimization for TensorFlow, Keras and PyTorch

issue.body:
It would be great if possible to allow the option of using multi-output Keras models. 

It is currently stated in Scan.py that y should have shape (m, c) where c is the number of classes. This restricts to one output parameter and inputting a multi-output model yields the following error:
~/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/talos/scan/scan_prepare.py in scan_prepare(self)
     57 
     58     # create the data asset
---> 59     self.y_max = self.y.max()
     60     self = validation_split(self)
     61     self.shape = classify(self.y)

AttributeError: 'list' object has no attribute 'max'

For example the model I am currently working with outputs Age, Species, and Status where each has a different value of c in the shape (m, c).

body:
This works now in @daily-dev. You can see some information in a related spectrum chat [here](https://spectrum.chat/?t=32b7113b-65e9-4140-8f70-c7a296283572). I've tried the following cases: 

First: 

```
import numpy as np

from keras.layers import Input, Dense, Dropout
from keras.models import Model

x = np.random.randn(100,10);
y = np.random.randn(100,1);

import sys
sys.path.insert(0, '/Users/mikko/Documents/GitHub/talos')
import talos as ta

p = {'dropout' : [0.1]}

```
And then first case where model.fit() input is list: 

```
def input_model(x_train, y_train, x_val, y_val, params):

    inputs = Input(shape=(x.shape[1],))
    inputs_2 = Input(shape=(x.shape[1],))

    layer = Dense(20)(inputs)
    layer = Dropout(params['dropout'])(layer)
    outputs = Dense(1)(layer)
    model = Model([inputs, inputs_2], outputs)
    model.compile(loss='mse', optimizer='adam')

    history = model.fit(x=[x_train, x_train],
                        y=y_train,
                        validation_data=[[x_val, x_val], y_val],
                        batch_size=10,
                        epochs=2,
                        verbose=1)
    
    return history, model

ta.Scan(x, y, p, input_model, x_val=x, y_val=y)
```
And second case where Scan() x is list:

```
def input_model(x_train, y_train, x_val, y_val, params):

    inputs = Input(shape=(x.shape[1],))
    inputs_2 = Input(shape=(x.shape[1],))

    layer = Dense(20)(inputs)
    layer = Dropout(params['dropout'])(layer)
    outputs = Dense(1)(layer)
    model = Model([inputs, inputs_2], outputs)
    model.compile(loss='mse', optimizer='adam')

    history = model.fit(x=x_train,
                        y=y_train,
                        validation_data=[x_val, y_val],
                        batch_size=10,
                        epochs=2,
                        verbose=1)
    
    return history, model

ta.Scan([x, x], y, p, input_model, x_val=[x, x], y_val=y)
```
The key point here is that you **must declare the `Scan(...x_val, y_val...) ` arguments as otherwise Talos will try to split the data and this will not work.

issue.title: How to pass a dict of data?

labels.name: topic: data
labels.description: Has to do with input or output data

repository.name: talos
repository.description: Hyperparameter Optimization for TensorFlow, Keras and PyTorch

issue.body:
I have collected all my data in a `dict` called `data`. This is convenient for me since my model takes multiple inputs, let's call them `x_0, x_1`. I can access these numpy arrays as for instance `data['val']['x_0']` for my validation data of `x_0`, or `data['test']['y']` for my test data of targets. 

Furthermore (this shouldn't matter, but let me mention it, so that it is hopefully less confusing), inside the model creation function passed to Talos, I have defined another `dict` called `hp`, which collects all hyperparameters used by my Keras model. This is *not* used as the `params` of the Talos API. 

To explain what I want to do, let me show a simplified example of what my standard (non-Talos) Keras script does:

```python
# Imports
import argparse
import numpy as np
import keras as ks
import talos as ta
# and so on ...

from my_functions import load_data, create_model, train

# Load data
data = load_data('./my_data.h5')

# Set hyperparameters
hp = {'epochs'                     : 1000,
      'batch_size'                 : 256,
      'loss'                       : 'logcosh'}

# Build model
model = create_model(input_shapes=[data['train']['x_0'].shape[1:], data['train']['x_1'].shape[1:]], params=hp)

# Train
history, model = train(model=model, data=data, params=hp)https://lichess.org/Hsz1YtxYjdRM

# Evaluate (predicting on test set and saving plots)
evaluate(model=model, data=data, params=hp, dirs=dirs, verbose=verbose)
```


The following is how I've tried the integration with Talos:

```python
# Imports
import argparse
import numpy as np
import keras as ks
import talos as ta
# and so on ...

from my_functions import load_data, create_model, train

# Load data
data = load_data('./my_data.h5')

params = {'batch_size'                 : [128, 256, 512],
          'loss'                       : ['mae', 'logcosh']}

def talos_model(data, params):
    # Set hyperparameters
    hp = {'epochs'                     : 1000,
          'batch_size'                 : params['batch_size'],
          'loss'                       : params['loss']}

    # Build model
    model = create_model(input_shapes=[data['train']['x_0'].shape[1:], data['train']['x_1'].shape[1:]], params=hp)

    # Train
    history, model = train(model=model, data=data, params=hp)

    # Evaluate (predicting on test set and saving plots)
    evaluate(model=model, data=data, params=hp, dirs=dirs, verbose=verbose)

    return history, model

h = ta.Scan(x=[ data['train']['x_0'], data['train']['x_1'] ], # I'm unsure what to put here
            y=data['train']['y'],
            model=talos_model,
            params=params)

```



However, the validation split seems to fail because the data is not structured as Talos expects it to. Here is the traceback:

```python
Using TensorFlow backend.
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "main.py", line 102, in <module>
    grid_downsample=0.1)
  File "/home/ffaye/miniconda3/envs/py3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/talos/scan/Scan.py", line 166, in __init__
    self._null = self.runtime()
  File "/home/ffaye/miniconda3/envs/py3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/talos/scan/Scan.py", line 170, in runtime
    self = scan_prepare(self)
  File "/home/ffaye/miniconda3/envs/py3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/talos/scan/scan_prepare.py", line 60, in scan_prepare
    self = validation_split(self)
  File "/home/ffaye/miniconda3/envs/py3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/talos/utils/validation_split.py", line 18, in validation_split
    random_shuffle(self)
  File "/home/ffaye/miniconda3/envs/py3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/talos/utils/validation_split.py", line 42, in random_shuffle
    self.x = self.x[random_index]
TypeError: only integer scalar arrays can be converted to a scalar index
```

**Questions:** 

1. How can I input my data in a way that makes sense to Talos (preferably without rewriting all my functions)? What are the rules for what can be the arguments for `talos_model`?
2. How can I specify that I would like to use my `[ data['val'][x_0], data['val'][x_1] ], data['val'][y]` as validation data, instead of Talos making the split from my training data?

**Other remarks** (forgive me if these are known issues, or non-issues):
1. In the [Talos user manual](https://github.com/autonomio/talos/blob/master/docs/index.rst), `reduction_metric` is not explained anywhere.
2. If `grid_downsample` is too low a Python `IndexError` will be thrown. Maybe it would be better to have a Talos error message explaining what is happening?
3. Thank you very much for writing this amazing piece of software! I really hope my issues can be resolved, so that I can start using it! :)

EDIT: This may be addressed by https://github.com/autonomio/talos/issues/132#issuecomment-440675546, but the thread was a bit cluttered, and I'm not fully sure it applies to my scenario (or indeed if the mentioned local branch with the potential fix is available at the time of writing).

body: In your example, your input_model function still takes in a numpy array for x_train. Is there a way to pass in a list for x_train?

issue.title: How do I pass in a list of inputs?

repository.name: talos
repository.description: Hyperparameter Optimization for TensorFlow, Keras and PyTorch

issue.body:
In most talos code examples, X input seems to be a 2D numpy array.
But in some of my keras models, it requires a list of 2D numpy arrays because my models are not `Sequential`.
Example list: `[numpyarray1, numpyarray2, numpyarray3]`.

It seems that when I try to pass this list to the `ta.Scan` function, things break.

How do I pass in a list of inputs?

Also, I'm not sure if `talos` supports `pandas` DataFrame or not. But I think it does not support so please do make support for it.

issue.title: list input AttributeError: 'list' object has no attribute 'max'

repository.name: talos
repository.description: Hyperparameter Optimization for TensorFlow, Keras and PyTorch

issue.body:
Hi

I'm using below model with talos : 

my input is alist of sevent arrays like this 

`X_train = [ f0_train_tw,   f1_train_tw,  f2_train_tw, f3_train_tw , f4_one_tr,  f5_train_preds  , f6_train]

Y_train = [Y_oh_tr, Ymrs_train, Y_oh_tr]

and test 

X_test = [ f0_test_tw,   f1_test_tw,  f2_test_tw, f3_test_tw , f4_test_tr,  f5_test_preds  , f6_test]

Y_train = [Y_oh_tr, Ymrs_train, Y_oh_tr]


`
`
    
def my_model(  x_train, y_train, x_val, y_val, params  ):
.
.
.

    loss = dict(
        m_out_reg= 'mse',
        out_bias   = 'categorical_crossentropy',
        out_reg2clf= 'categorical_crossentropy'
    )
    metrics = dict(
        m_out_reg = 'mae',
        out_bias  = 'accuracy',
        out_reg2clf = 'accuracy'

    )
    loss_weights = dict(
           m_out_reg = 20,
           out_bias   = 1,
           out_reg2clf=1

    )
    model.compile(optimizer=opti, loss=loss, metrics=metrics, loss_weights=loss_weights)
    
    
    
    pth_r = 'drive/Colab_Notebooks/dnn_logs/5400/checkpoint_r_con_seq_rnn.hdf5'

    pth_r2c = 'drive/Colab_Notebooks/dnn_logs/5400/checkpoint_r2c_con_seq_rnn.hdf5'



    reduceLR = ReduceLROnPlateau(monitor='loss', factor=0.42, patience=9, verbose=1, mode='auto', cooldown=10)
    chkpt_c = ModelCheckpoint(pth_c, monitor='val_out_bias_acc', mode='max', verbose=2, save_best_only=True, save_weights_only=True, period=1)
    chkpt_r = ModelCheckpoint(pth_r, monitor='val_m_out_reg_mean_absolute_error', mode='min', verbose=2, save_best_only=True, save_weights_only=True, period=1)
    chkpt_r2c = ModelCheckpoint(pth_r2c, monitor='val_out_reg2clf_acc', mode='max', verbose=2, save_best_only=True, save_weights_only=True, period=1)
    
    out = model.fit( x= [X_train[0] ,X_train[1],X_train[2] ,X_train[3] ,X_train[4] ,X_train[5] ,X_train[6]]
                    , y=Y_train,
                    epochs=150,
                    batch_size=params['batch_size'],
                  
                    validation_data = [[X_test[0] ,X_test[1] ,X_test[2] ,X_test[3] ,X_test[4] ,X_test[5] ,X_test[6]], Y_test],
                    
                    callbacks = [chkpt_r, chkpt_c, chkpt_r2c, reduceLR] , class_weight =class_weight)
`

Then I call talos like this : 

`ta.Scan(X_train,  Y_train , p, input_model,  x_val=X_test , y_val=Y_test )
`


I get this error :
